properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.action: Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
properties.location: Kennedys Creek, between Sheepyard Track and King Track
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Kennedys Creek, between Sheepyard Track and King Track.
  • There is a bushfire at 2.5Km East Of Kennedys Creek that is not yet under control.
  •  The bushfire is travelling from Sheepyard Track in a south-easterly direction towards King Track.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or Colac.
Impacts in your area:
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 03:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Duchembegarra, East Natimuk, Grass Flat, Natimuk, Quantong, Vectis, Vectis East, Vectis South, Lower Norton
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Duchembegarra, East Natimuk, Grass Flat, Lower Norton, Natimuk, Quantong, Vectis, Vectis East, Vectis South.
  • The fire in the Natimuk, Quantong and Vectis area is not yet under control.
  • Firefighters have been able to slow the spread of the fire in the Quantong and Vectis area for now, but this can change at any time and the situation is still dangerous. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • Natimuk residents and those in areas west of the Wimmera River who have remained at their properties should stay alert over night.
  •  This Watch and Act message replaces the Emergency Warning Shelter Indoors issued at 5.53pm Friday 9th January 2026. 
Staying close to a building where you can shelter is the safest option, as conditions can change suddenly.

Continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do:
  • Monitor changes, including increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility that indicates the situation is changing. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If the situation changes you will need to leave quickly. Plan to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
Impacts in your area:
  • Wimmera Highway between Nhill-Harrow Road and the Horsham Noradjuha Road Natimuk Frances Road is closed at Gymbowen, with traffic diverted to Nhill.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 
  • NBN connected phone and internet services will not work during a power outage. You will not be able to call Triple Zero (000) using your home phone.
  • A relief Centre is open at the Horsham Town Hall, Wilson Street Horsham. This centre will remain open over night.

This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Sutton Grange, Elphinstone, Harcourt North, Metcalfe, Sedgwick
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Elphinstone, Harcourt North, Metcalfe, Sedgwick, Sutton Grange.
  • There is a grassfire travelling from Fogarty Gap Road, Ravenswood in a easterly direction that is not yet under control. 
  •  The fire crossed Calder Highway and has impacted Mount Alexander and areas to the east.
  • People at Elphinstone, Harcourt North, Metcalfe, Sedgwick and Sutton Grange should leave immediately. 
  • When leaving the area, travel north towards Bendigo via the Sedgwick Road or south towards Kyneton via the Sutton Grange Road.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Watch and Act message issued at 9:07pm on Friday, 9 January 2026.
Elphinstone, Harcourt North, Metcalfe, Sedgwick and Sutton Grange could be impacted at anytime. Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous.
What you should do
  • When you leave take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
Travel to:
  • Relief centre located at Kyneton Toyota Sports & Aquatic Centre at 4 Victoria Street, Kyneton and Bendigo Showgrounds in North Bendigo accessible by Holmes Road.
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
In the car:
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights; smoke will make it difficult to see.
Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.  

If you are unable to leave, seek shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents.
  • Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to harm you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window, including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt.
Impacts in your area:
The following roads are closed: 
  • Fogarty Gap Road between the Calder Freeway and Walmer Road
  • Midland Highway between Castlemaine and Harcourt
  • Calder Freeway southbound from Ravenswood
  • Calder freeway northbound from Malmsbury
  • Intersection of the Old Calder Highway and Pyrenees Highway
  • Intersection of Sutton Grange Road and Lyall Road at Redesdale 
  • Intersection of Sutton Grange Road and Blackfellows Gate Road
  • Intersection of Sutton Grange Road and Sedgewick Road
  • Intersection of Axe Creek Road and Patons Road.
This messages was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Castella, Kinglake, Kinglake Central, Kinglake East, Kinglake West, Pheasant Creek, Toolangi.
  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is not yet under control.
  • A wind change has occurred on the evening of Friday 9th January and impacted the fireground. This has caused the fire to change direction toward the east (towards Lake Eildon).
  • While fire behaviour has reduced, the fire is not contained and is still spreading. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or to:
Emergency Relief Centres:
  • Lilydale High School Basketball Stadium, 26 Hutchinson Street, Lilydale 
  • For caravans and trailers - Lilydale Recreation Reserve / Showgrounds, Market Street, Liliydale.
  • City of Whittlesea Civic Centre, 25 Ferres Blvd, South Morang

Impacts in your area:

  • Maroondah Highway and Devon Road

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Colac Colac and Nariel Valley..

  • There is a bushfire at 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control.
  • The bushfire moving in your direction.
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 9.22pm. 
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave. Leaving now would be deadly.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 04:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Mitta Valley including Tallandoon, Eskdale, Mitta Mitta, Dartmouth and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Mitta Valley including Tallandoon, Eskdale, Mitta Mitta, Dartmouth and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire moving in your direction.
  • The bushfire is moving in a southerly direction from the northern end of the Tallangatta Valley. 
  • The bushfire is out of control.
  • Leave to Wodonga using the Omeo Highway to Lockharts Gap Road. 
  • There is a relief centre at Wodonga Racecourse which allows pets. 
Fire conditions are changing and becoming more dynamic. Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
  • Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 04:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Faraday, Harcourt, Harcourt North.
  • There is a grassfire travelling from Fogarty Gap Road, Ravenswood in a easterly direction that is not yet under control. 
  •  The fire crossed Calder Highway and has impacted Mount Alexander and areas to the east
  • If you have not already left, the time to safely evacuate has now passed. Take shelter indoors immediately. It is now too dangerous to leave.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 9:05 pm.
You are in danger, act now to protect yourself. It is too late to leave. The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately.
What you should do:

Quickly move indoors:
  • Bring your pets indoors.
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. 
  • Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to harm you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window, including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve. 
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or in-ground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
In the car:
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights; smoke will make it difficult to see.
If caught in fire:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights. 
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed:
  • Fogarty Gap Road between the Calder Freeway and Walmer Road
  • Midland Highway between Castlemaine and Harcourt 
  • Calder Freeway southbound from Ravenswood 
  • Calder freeway northbound from Malmsbury 
  • Intersection of the Old Calder Highway and Pyrenees Highway
  • Intersection of Sutton Grange Road and Lyall Road at Redesdale  
  • Intersection of Sutton Grange Road and Blackfellows Gate Road 
  • Intersection of Sutton Grange Road and Sedgewick Road 
  • Intersection of Axe Creek Road and Patons Road .

  • Grassfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the flames reach you. 
  • Grassfires can start and spread quickly, and are extremely dangerous.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.action: Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Carranballac, Skipton, Streatham. 
  • There is a bushfire at Yalla-Y-Poora Rd, Streatham that is not yet under control. The bushfire is travelling from Skipton in a easterly direction towards Pitfield.
  • Firefighters have been able to slow the spread of the fire for now, but this can change at any time and the situation is still dangerous. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or Beaufort Community Bank Complex - 3 Park Road Beaufort.
Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed: 
  • Glenelg Hwy between Pittong to Streatham.
  • Geelong Road at Pitfield
  • Eurambeen-Streatham Road from Streatham to Mt William Road.
  • Carngham Road to Mt William Road.
  • Beaufort-Skipton Road at Carngham Rd
  • Lismore-Skipton Road between Lismore and Skipton.
Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 03:20 am or as the situation changes.  

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Hotline on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Beetoomba, Berringama, Lucyvale.

  • There is a bushfire at 27Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling in a south-westerly direction. 
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave. Leaving now would be deadly.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.
  • Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 02:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Acheron, Devils River, Eildon, Taylor Bay, Thornton
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Acheron, Devils River, Eildon, Taylor Bay, Thornton.

  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is not yet under control.
  • A wind change has occurred on the evening of Friday 9th January and impacted the fireground. This has caused the fire to change direction toward the east (towards Lake Eildon). While fire behaviour has reduced, the fire is not contained and is still spreading. 
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too dangerous to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is dangerous late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed:
  • Maroondah Highway between Yea and Maindample
  • Maroondah Highway and Devon Road
  • Maroondah Highway between McKenzie Ave, Healesville to Anderson Lane, Narbethong
  • Merton Euroa Road closed through to the Hume Freeway  
  • McMenaman Rd and Maroondah Highway   
  • Kobyboyn Road and Highlands Road   
  • Ghin Ghin Road and Goulburn Valley Highway 
  • Faithfull Road at Hume Freeway 
  • Goulburn Valley Highway and Whatton Place
  • Tarcombe Road at Hume Freeway
Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Dahlen, Haven, Mckenzie Creek, Noradjuha, Pimpinio, Vectis. 
  • The fire in Natimuk, Quantong and Vectis area is not yet under control.
  • Firefighters have been able to slow the spread of the fire at Quantong and Vectis for now, but this can change at any time and the situation is still dangerous you must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • Natimuk residents and those in the areas west of the Wimmera River who have remained at their properties should stay alert overnight. 
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Emergency Warning - Leave immediately issued at 3.35pm Friday 9th January 2026. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or Horsham.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Wimmera Highway between Nhill-Harrow Road and the Horsham Noradjuha Road Natimuk Frances Road is closed at Gymbowen, with traffic diverted to Nhill.
  • NBN connected phone and internet services will not work during a power outage. You will not be able to call Triple Zero (000) using your home phone.
  • A relief Centre is open at the Horsham Town Hall, Wilson Street Horsham. This centre will remain open overnight.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 09:20 am or as the situation changes.  

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Culloden, Glenaladale, Stockdale, The Fingerboards, Briagolong, Cobbannah, Fernbank, Iguana Creek, Moornapa, Walpa, Woodglen, Wuk Wuk
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Briagolong, Cobbannah, Culloden, Fernbank, Glenaladale, Iguana Creek, Moornapa, Stockdale, The Fingerboards, Walpa, Woodglen, Wuk Wuk. 
  • It is strongly recommended you Prepare to Leave. 
  • The bushfire is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Dargo in a south-easterly direction towards the warning area. 
  • Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire.
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 8:32pm.
Prepare to Leave immediately. Leave as soon as you are ready, as roads will become busy as people leave.

What you should do:
  • Monitor the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can mean the situation is worsening.
  • Protect yourself and your family.
  • If you are not prepared, leave now. Dont wait until it is too late - leave early. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If you are leaving, pack: 
  • Cash 
  • Clothing for three days 
  • Medicine for three days 
  • Phone and chargers 
  • Toiletries 
  • Important documents 
  • Meaningful items and photos 
  • Pet essentials, including leash and carriers.
Check on your neighbours if it is safe.

Check the VicTraffic website for road closures.

Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 

Where to go:
  • Friends or family away from the fire. 
  • Consider roads may become busy closer to the time of impact. 

Impacts in your area: 
  • Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 10:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Carlisle River, between Pipeline Road and Trotters lane.
  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River that is not yet under control.
  •  The bushfire is travelling from Trotters Lane (north) in a south-easterly direction towards Trotters Lane (south).
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Black Snake Creek, Blomford, Budgee Budgee, Castleburn, Cobbannah, Cowa, Crooked River, Dargo, Gibbs, Grant, Hawkhurst, Hogtown, Howittville, Hunter Corner, Maguires, Miowera, Moornapa, Moroka, Naarun, Peter the Swede, Shepherdson, Talbotville, Toolome, Treasure, Treasures, Waterford, Winchester, Wongungarra, Woolenook, Arbuckle, Billabong, Briagolong, Glenaladale, Iguana Creek, Valencia Creek, Wrathung
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Arbuckle, Billabong, Black Snake Creek, Blomford, Briagolong, Budgee Budgee, Castleburn, Cobbannah, Cowa, Crooked River, Dargo, Gibbs, Glenaladale, Grant, Hawkhurst, Hogtown, Howittville, Hunter Corner, Iguana Creek, Maguires, Miowera, Moornapa, Moroka, Naarun, Peter the Swede, Shepherdson, Talbotville, Toolome, Treasure, Treasures, Valencia Creek, Waterford, Winchester, Wongungarra, Woolenook, Wrathung.

  • There is a bushfire at Mt Darling - Cynthia Range that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Wonnangatta road in a south-easterly direction towards Cobbannah. 
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency warning issued at 8:08pm. 
  • If you have not already left, the time to safely evacuate has now passed. Take shelter indoors immediately. It is now too dangerous to leave.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The following roads are closed: 
  • Bairnsdale Dargo Road at the Beverleys road junction
  • Freestone Creek Road at Coopers Road
  • Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is for Lyal, Myrtle Creek, Redesdale.
  • There is a grassfire travelling from Fogarty Gap Road, Ravenswood in a easterly direction that is not yet under control.
  • The fire has crossed Calder Highway and has impacted Mount Alexander and areas to the east.
  • When leaving the area, travel north towards Bendigo via the Sedgwick Road or south towards Kyneton via the Sutton Grange Road.
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 7:44pm on Friday, 9 January 2026.
Don't wait - If you are not prepared to stay, leaving now is the safest option. Conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do:

The best protection from radiant heat and smoke is distance.

Travel to:
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • Relief centre located at Kyneton Toyota Sports & Aquatic Centre at 4 Victoria Street, Kyneton and Bendigo Showgrounds in North Bendigo accessible by Holmes Road.
  • When you leave, remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
  • If you encounter smoke or flames while travelling, turn around and drive to safety. If you're unable to turn around and drive to safety, a car offers more protection from the fire's heat than being caught on foot in the open.
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
In the car:
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you choose to stay, seek shelter indoors: 
  • Bring your pets indoors.
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents.
  • Turn off cooling systems.
  • Shelter in a room that has a door and a window to the outside so you can keep an eye on what is happening with the fire.
Impacts in your area:

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Boho South, Harrys Creek, Kelvin View, Lima, Lima East, Marraweeney, Violet Town, Warrenbayne.
  • The Longwood fire is not yet under control.
  • A wind change has occurred on the evening of Friday 9th January and impacted the fireground. This has caused the fire to change direction toward the east (towards Lake Eildon).
  • While fire behaviour has reduced, the fire is not contained and is still spreading. 
The situation can change at any time. 

You must monitor conditions and be ready to act. Conditions will be very dangerous and unpredictable.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires.
Impacts in your area:
The following roads are closed:
  • Maroondah Highway between Yea and Maindample

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Granya, Bungil, Burrowye,  Walwa and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Granya, Bungil, Burrowye, Walwa and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control. 
  • The bushfire is burning in Mt Lawson State Park and travelling in a south/south easterly direction. 
  • Properties within the warning area could be impacted. 
  • A wind change is expected early tomorrow morning. This will cause the fire to change direction. Conditions can become very dangerous and unpredictable. 
  • It is important to note that this wind change information is based off a predicted forecast only. 
  • Relief Centre is available at the Wodonga Racecourse.
  • Please read below for road closure information.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 6:50 pm.
Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, a fully charged mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Burrowye and Walwa can travel to Albury/Wodonga via NSW roads, which can be accessed at the river crossing at Jingellic Road.  
  • Residents from Thologolong to Granya should travel to Albury/Wodonga west along the Murray River Road.
  • For NSW fire information click here

Road Closure - Emergency Vehicles Only:
  • Shelley Road.
  • Murray River Road between Granya Road and Jingellic Rd. 
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 02:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.

  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Acheron, Limestone, Whanregarwen, Yea.

  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is not yet under control.
  • A wind change has occurred and impacted the fireground. This has caused the fire to change direction toward the east (toward Alexandra).
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area:

  • Merton Euroa Road closed through to the Hume Freeway 
  • McMenaman Road and Maroondah Highway 
  • Kobyboyn Road and Highlands Road 
  • Ghin Ghin Road and Goulbourn Valley Highway 
  • Maroondah Highway and Devon Road 
  • Goulbourn Valley Highway and Whatton Place 
  • Faithfull Road at Hume Freeway  
  • Tarcombe Road at Hume Freeway  
  • Maroondah Highway between Yea and Maindample
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

properties.location: Creightons Creek, Dropmore, Gobur, Gooram, Kanumbra, Kelvin View, Locksley, Longwood East, Ruffy, Tarcombe, Terip Terip, Upton Hill, Caveat, Highlands, Longwood, Strathbogie
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Caveat, Creightons Creek, Dropmore, Gobur, Gooram, Highlands, Kanumbra, Kelvin View, Locksley, Longwood, Longwood East, Ruffy, Strathbogie, Tarcombe, Terip Terip, Upton Hill.

  • The Longwood fireis not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling in a south-easterly direction but conditions are dynamic.   
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
A wind change is imminent 
This will cause the fire to change direction to the north east heading back towards Strathbogie. Conditions will become very dangerous and unpredictable!
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 

The following roads are closed:
  • Merton Euroa Road closed through to the Hume Freeway 
  • McMenaman Road and Maroondah Highway 
  • Kobyboyn Road and Highlands Road 
  • Ghin Ghin Road and Goulbourn Valley Highway 
  • Maroondah Highway and Devon Road 
  • Goulbourn Valley Highway and Whatton Place 
  • Faithfull Road at Hume Freeway  
  • Tarcombe Road at Hume Freeway  
  • Maroondah Highway between Yea and Maindample 
  • Maroondah Highway from McKenzie Avenue Healsville
There are Emergency Relief Centres operating: 
  • Seymour Sports and Aquatics Centre (Chittick Park), Pollard St Seymour 
  • Benalla Town Hall, 82-86 Nunn Street Benalla
To register that you are safe or for enquiries regarding residents in the fire area go online to Register Find Reunite https://register.redcross.org.au/
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Emergency Warning is being issued for Barkers Creek, Ravenswood South, Walmer.
  • There is a grassfire travelling from Fogarty Gap Road, Ravenswood in a easterly direction that is not yet under control. 
  • The fire crossed Calder Highway and has impacted Mount Alexander and areas to the east.
  • If you have not already left, the time to safely evacuate has now passed. Take shelter indoors immediately. It is now too dangerous to leave.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 9:04pm.
You are in danger, act now to protect yourself. It is too late to leave. The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately.
Do not get in the car and drive. It is safer to stay where you are.
What you should do:

Quickly move indoors:
  • Bring your pets indoors.
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. 
  • Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to harm you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window, including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve. 
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or in-ground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
In the car:
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights; smoke will make it difficult to see.
If caught in fire:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights. 
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed:
  • Fogarty Gap Road between the Calder Freeway and Walmer Road
  • Midland Highway between Castlemaine and Harcourt
  • Calder Freeway southbound from Ravenswood
  • Calder freeway northbound from Malmsbury

  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

properties.location: Pilchers Bridge, Axe Creek, Myrtle Creek, Sedgwick
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Axe Creek, Myrtle Creek, Pilchers Bridge, Sedgwick.
  • There is a bushfire at Axe Creek Road, Sedgwick that is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Axe Creek Road in a easterly direction towards Curtis Road.
  • Firefighters have been able to slow the spread of fire for now, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • Further warnings have been issued for a grassfire travelling from Fogarty Gap Road, Ravenswood that has impacted Mount Alexander and areas to the east.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued Friday at 6.26pm.
Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing.
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Current winds in catastrophic conditions can be very unpredictable and can move the fire in multiple directions.
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.
  • Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire.
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: Cambarville, Granton, Marysville, Narbethong, St Fillans, Wilks Creek
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Cambarville, Granton, Marysville, Narbethong, St Fillans, Wilks Creek.
  • It replaces the emergency warning issued earlier today, however conditions are changing quickly and you must pay attention. 
  • The Longwood fire is not yet under control.
  •  The bushfire is travelling from Alexandra in a south-easterly direction towards Marysville.
A wind change was expected around 8:00pm tonight (Friday 9 January) that will cause the fire to change direction to the north east, heading back towards Strathbogie.
Conditions are still dangerous and can change at any time. You MUST monitor conditions and be ready to act if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or to the relief center at:
Lilydale High School Basketball Stadium, 
26 Hutchinson Street, Lilydale
For caravans and trailers - Lilydale Recreation Reserve / Showgrounds, 
Market Street, Liliydale.
Impacts in your area:
  • Maroondah Highway between Yea and Maindample
  • Maroondah Highway and Devon Road  
  • Merton Euroa Road closed through to the Hume Freeway  
  • McMenaman Rd and Maroondah Highway   
  • Kobyboyn Road and Highlands Road   
  • Ghin Ghin Road and Goulburn Valley Highway  
  • Faithfull Road at Hume Freeway  
  • Goulburn Valley Highway and Whatton Place  
  • Tarcombe Road at Hume Freeway

Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 06:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Darbyshire, Koetong, Shelley.

  • There is a bushfire at 27Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control.
  • The fire is expected to impact this location imminently. 
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 9:21pm. 
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.
  • Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire.
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 04:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning to Evacuate Immediately is being issued for Tallangatta Valley, Bullioh and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire at 27Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control. 
  • There is a bushfire moving in your direction. 
  • Leave and go to Tallangatta or Wodonga. 
  • There are relief centres at Tallangatta Memorial Hall or Wodonga Racecourse. 
If you choose to stay, emergency services may not be able to help you.
If you are located in Tallangatta Valley and Bullioh, it is recommended you evacuate immediately and move to a safer location away from the fire. Go to Tallangatta/Wodonga on the Murray Valley Highway. 
What you should do: 

Evacuate immediately: 
  • Evacuate immediately with all members of your household. 
  • When you leave, remember to take your pets, mobile phone and charger. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return. 
Travel to a safer location. Options include: 
  • A relief centre is open at Tallangatta Memorial Hall and Wodonga Racecourse. 
  • The home of family or friends away from the warning area. 
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see. 
If you are unable to leave, you should seek shelter inside: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots and heavy duty leather gloves. 
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • Shelter in a room that has a door and or a window to the outside. The building can protect you from radiant heat. It is critical to keep an eye on what is happening with the fire. 
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so youll need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you.
  • Embers are being carried by the wind large distances ahead of the main fire and starting spot fires.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 02:10 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Baring, Big Desert, Boinka, Linga, Patchewollock, Torrita, Underbool, Walpeup. 
  • The a bushfire that started at South of Boinka is not yet under control. 
  • The spread of the bushfire has slowed for now, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • It is safe to return to the area. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act - Prepare to Leave issued at 7.24pm. 
The threat is reduced, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or Relief Centre at Blackburn Park Farrell Street Ouyen.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The following roads are closed: 
  • Hopetoun -  Road at the intersection of Lascelles West Road. 
  • Ouyen - Patchewollock Road at Ouyen.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for smoke across the State of Victoria.
  • You will see or smell smoke in parts of Victoria.
  • The smoke is a result of a multiple bushfires and grassfires burning across various parts of the state.
  • Smoke and ash from fires in the landscape may drift to far-reaching areas away from the fires.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
What you should do:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: 
  • Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last smoke message issued.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
